Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing Hypotheses About Fire Using Data Syntheses and Fire Modeling

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will investigate how changes in environmental and human activities have influenced fires over time, using a combination of datasets that describe past and present variations in fire. The project also will develop a global fire model to help test hypotheses about the roles that environmental factors and humans have played in controlling the location, size, and frequency of fires at regional-to-global scales. The project will provide new information and insights about relationships among fire, climate and other environmental factors, and human activities. The project will contribute to broader scientific advances in knowledge regarding Earth system processes, and the project will enhance the quality of Earth system models that now are incorporating fire in simulations of the global environment. Knowledge of the ways that human activity, climate, and other environmental factors have affected fires in the past at both regional and global scales is critical to understanding how fires will behave in the future. Given the threats that fires pose for humans and the critical role that fires play in the functioning of many ecosystems, increased awareness of the dynamics of fire behavior has considerable practical utility. Project findings will facilitate enable improved representations of the processes that control fire in models across a variety of climate and land-use conditions, thereby informing decisions about natural resource and fire management efforts. The project will provide education and training opportunities for graduate students, and it will assist in the development of curricular materials dealing with the interactions among fire, natural systems, and human activities for use in elementary and secondary schools.

This project will use satellite-based reconstructions of fire activity to validate modern-day simulations, and it will advance collection of data to study the factors that have influenced the dynamics and impact of fire in the past. The investigators will combine information from a still-expanding global database of fire over the last millennium with the outputs from global fire modeling. Past fire activity will be estimated from charcoal particles in lake sediments at a given depth as well as the time when the charcoal was deposited as determined through the use of radiocarbon dating. The charcoal records will be used to reconstruct past levels of fire activity under a range of climate and land-use conditions, and the reconstructions will be compared with various simulations of past global fire activity. Combining past and present datasets with model simulations of past climate will provide a more rigorous basis for understanding the specific processes that produce reconstructed and observed changes in fire activity than modern-day (satellite) datasets alone.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project ?Testing Hypotheses About Fire Using Data Syntheses and Fire Modeling? was aimed at developing a better understanding of the history of fire on Earth through the development and integration of long-term fire history datasets and models.   The project was a collaboration among researchers at Yale University (Jennifer Marlon), the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (Brian Magi), and the University of Oregon (Patrick Bartlein).  Some of the key findings of the overall project included:

  • the development of new spatially-explicit (gridded) reconstructions of global biomass burning for the past 21,000 and 1000 years that show unprecedented contemporary fire activity in several disparate regions of the world; 
  • a global emissions inventory that includes long-term fire-history information from charcoal records for broad use by the global climate and Earth system modeling communities; and 
  • insights into the unique fire signatures produced by different land-use and land-cover types in both charcoal data and models. This latter finding revealed unique Holocene biomass burning trajectories in forest versus grasslands, highlighting the importance of disaggregating these types of records in future fire emissions inventories. 

 

The project team also produced a new version of the Global Charcoal Database (v3) and developed global comparisons of independent fire-history datasets ? from satellites, airport visibility records, fire-scarred trees, and historical sources ? that have increased our confidence in and understanding of reconstructions of sediment-based charcoal data. This new knowledge lays a foundation for more precise and robust fire-history reconstructions in the future, whether applied to issues in fire ecology and management, conservation, or Earth system modeling.  More specific details of the research at Yale and UNCC can be obtained by searching for the Award ID numbers of those subprojects (Yale:  1437074, UNCC:  1436496) 

Work at the University of Oregon focused on the development of data-analysis tools for using the charcoal database to answer questions about the role of fire in the Earth system currently, and in the future.  For example, the paper by Harrison et al. (2018) sought to estimate the strength ?climate-carbon-cycle feedback?:   As global carbon dioxide emissions increase from both natural and human sources, that results in increases in global temperatures, and because fire strongly depends on temperature, to increases in biomass burning.  Greater burning results in decreases in the amount of carbon stored in the terrestrial biosphere and to increases in emissions, and thus to further warming.  The paper used paleo records of atmospheric composition and temperature over the past two millennia, derived from ice-core and tree-ring records, along with a global biomass burning record derived from the Global Charcoal Database (Fig. 1), to derive the biomass-burning feedback parameter (5.6 +/- 3.2 ppm CO2 per degree of land temperature change) (Fig. 2).  This value was in good agreement with the value of the feedback parameter developed using satellite remote-sensing records of biomass burning and observed climate and carbon dioxide emissions over the past two decades).  The feedback parameter, while small at first glance, shows that biomass burning, which is projected to increase in the future, can indeed lead to further increases in emissions and to further warming.   

In addition to using the tools developed for analyzing the charcoal database (https://pjbartlein.github.io/GCDv3Analysis/), the paper illustrated an example of ?reproducible research?, but providing a ?script? for full data analysis using open-source software (https://doi.org/10.5194/esd-9-663-2018-supplement).  This allows other researchers to see how the analysis was done in detail, and to easily use it as a ?point-of-departure? for further analyses.

Harrison, S. P., Bartlein, P. J., Brovkin, V., Houweling, S., Kloster, S., & Prentice, I. C. (2018). The biomass burning contribution to climate?carbon-cycle feedback. Earth Syst. Dynam., 9(2), 663-677. https://doi.org/10.5194/esd-9-663-2018
